text: Patient: and the chemo. Doctor: the chemo and that’s a nationwide study so, you know, we would pretty much kind of consider that one for you. And then there’s another trial of just pills. You say, listen, Dr. H____ there’s no way your’e giving me any more chemo, get away from me, then there’s a study with two pills so the one pill that I would offer you and then another pill that is also FDA approved but you know in cancer it’s like hey, one’s good, let’s try two. So, the combo isn’t chemo plus pill, but it’s pill plus pill. How are we doing? Patient: I’m there. Doctor: Yeah, I can see it. text: Patient: I’ll get these tests done and then we’ll come back to see you. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Patient: And then the rest is done here? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: The treatment is here? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: The radium since it’s an injection is it IV injection or just a shot? Doctor: It is. No, they put a little IV in and then they kind of push it in over a minute and then you’re good for the month. Now, technically that’s liquid radiation so you’re kind of glowy. Patient: Ah. Okay. Doctor: So, do I advise that you go to the airport or to the Canadian border right after? No. Patient: No, that would not. Doctor: that’s not a good idea, no, no. But, you know, within a matter of like a few days it’s out. Now, its reasonably compared to all the other radiopharmaceuticals, easier to clean up. So, for example, if, and just for the record it’s like a fifteen thousand dollar vial. If you are oops and it lands on the floor, you don’t have to evacuate the building. Actually, what you do is you just put a piece of paper on there and then it’s protected. So, the half-life is really short but because it’s swirling in you as a human and then it stays in your bone which is why it’s only in the bone because it only goes to bone, um you will glow a smidge. So, we don’t want you to have like a newborn held up to you because you still will emit some sort of radiation.

text: Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, man, no, we don’t take out anywhere close to your entire blood volume. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just like this much but to do that they have to sort of strain for the right cells. That’s why you’re hooked up to this machine that they have for like two and a half three hours. So, I always say, you know, bring something to read. They play movies. If you have to pee a lot, you bring a urinal so you don’t have to get up because if nurses will start screaming if you move and um there’s two ways. Like you have pretty good veins so um most of the time they can just do it straight from your veins. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They’ll tell us whether that’s possible. A bunch of other people you need a port for six weeks where they actually put it in your arm or your chest and they remove the stuff, you know, out and then when we’re done we pull it out. Now, go like this and you know that your veins are there. They’re not spectacular veins but I don’t think they’re terrible veins. So, it’s like three hours for us to do that procedure and then when you get it reinfused back on a Thursday this stuff comes back in a bag and you get it through Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: the IV it’s about an hour. How’s that for fancy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s FDA approved for a cool, hundred thousand dollars so your insurance has to say yes number one, now don’t look at me with those eyes of yours. Secondly, we help you through that so that’s on us and if it’s not approved you won’t get it because people can’t, there’s no way we can afford that so we just would leave that but I might just start there to see if we can get the insurance to cover it. Most insurances will cover it, most insurances. So, that’s one. Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Now, the study that goes with that it isn’t whether you get the medicine or not, that’s a done deal, our study is to know what happens to your immune system so every time we see you we take ah blood from you so that we measure. Okay, what is this guy who’s supposed to fight this kind of infection. What’s his level? And what about this gal’s cell? What was she supposed to do? You know, it’s like who’s sleeping on the job Patient: mm hmm.

text: Family Member: Okay, so then you’re looking at like, like combinations of drugs? Doctor: Yeah. Normally, we would keep you on the hormone -- forever at that point, unfortunately. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then, add things to them. Standardly, we would add another hormone, so you’d be on two. Research-wise, we would potentially consider these other drugs, particularly because of your mutation. Family Member: So, no chemo then? Doctor: No, not in, not in the short term. Family Member: Not for now. Okay. That’s good news. Doctor: You know, but someday maybe. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, it is an effective thing we use, but I think we have other things to try before. Family Member: Awesome. (sighs) Doctor: Okay?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
